From: Cisco IOS Configuration Fundamentals Command Reference
FuncDef: To display recorded memory events, use the **show memory events** command in privileged EXEC mode.

ParaDef.Info: (Optional) Displays the outstanding allocation events in the event buffer.
(Optional) Displays a summary of outstanding allocation events in the event buffer.

Examples: The following is sample output from the show memory events command:
When Type Block/Chunk DataPtr Size PID What Traceback/PC
[ Table 121 ] (#wp1548524) describes the significant fields shown in the display.
Table 121 show memory events Field Descriptions
| When | Time when the memory event was last seen by the system (in hours and days). |
| Block/Chunk/DataPtr | Number of memory events allocated. |
| Size | Amount of memory, in bytes, used by the task. |
| What | Name of the process that owns a block or fragment. |
The following is sample output from the show memory events command using the outstanding and summary keywords:
Router# show memory events outstanding summary
Last-Seen Type How-Many Size PID What Traceback/PC
[ Table 122 ] (#wp1548581) describes the significant fields shown in the display.
Table 122 show memory events Field Descriptions
| Last-Seen | Time when the memory event was last seen by the system (in hours and days). |
| How-Many | Number of memory events allocated. |
| Size | Amount of memory, in bytes, used by the task. |
| What | Name of the process that owns a block or fragment. |
ExtraInfo: Before you can enable the **show memory events** command, you must configure the **memory record events** command in global configuration mode.
